titleproper.value: Guide to the Revolutionary Communist Party Records <num>TAM.090</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Processed by Stacy Kinlock

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-07T14:35:08</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: The Revolutionary Communist Party (RCP) was a Maoist organization founded in 1975 as the successor to the Revolutionary Union (founded in 1968). The collection consists of central committee bulletins and position papers, as well as pamphlets, flyers, and items from related organizations of the era.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
The provenance of this collection is unknown. The accession number associated with this collection is 1993.006.

In the mid-1970's, the Party opposed busing, affirmative action, and Black Nationalism, believing them to be non-revolutionary policies. To demonstrate against U.S. expansionist policies they briefly occupied the Alamo. They were instrumental in the organization of the National United Workers Organization and the Unemployed Workers Organizing Committee. In 1982, after a three-year court battle, 17 members, the "Mao Tse Tung defendants", were acquitted of felony charges for allegedly violent activity at a demonstration in Washington, D.C. In 1989 the RCP won a supreme court ruling that flag burning falls under protection of the first amendment. Since 1975, they have published The Worker.

The collection provides good documentation on the political activities and positions of the RCP, but documentation of the RCP post-1980 is sparse. Many of the materials are undated, and there is no mention of individual members except of the chairman, Bob Avakian.

subject.value: African Americans -- Civil rights -- United States.
